Award.AbstractNarration:
In the current project, the PI will explore several questions and open problems in the area of symbolic dynamics. Dynamics is the study of closed systems whose elements evolve over time according to deterministic rules; some examples include planetary motion, or a particle's movement inside a box. Symbolic dynamics is the study of dynamics where the elements in question are infinite sequences of symbols, and the evolution over time comes from horizontally shifting the sequence. Symbolic dynamics was introduced as a tool for studying more complicated dynamical systems, but has become a fundamental area in its own right, with applications and connections ranging from computer science (e.g. data storage in binary) to statistical physics (e.g. the Ising model for magnetism). A current area of high activity is multidimensional symbolic dynamics, in which one considers not sequences, but multidimensional arrays of symbols, which can be shifted in any direction. Though the core definitions and ideas remain the same, there are remarkable changes that occur for multiple dimensions; many questions that were easy to answer in one dimension become quite difficult, and classes of systems whose behavior was relatively simple in one dimension can exhibit strange and complex behaviors.

The research supported by this grant will treat a variety of problems in symbolic dynamics, ranging from the more classical one-dimensional case to the less well-understood multidimensional case. A common thread throughout is the use of ideas, techniques, and viewpoints from other areas, including probability theory, statistical physics, and percolation theory, to attack fundamental problems. The two projects on one-dimensional symbolic dynamics propose new directions of research about the classical notions of follower sets and the specification property respectively. The first multidimensional project proposes a new method for the efficient approximation of entropies of multidimensional shifts of finite type (SFT) which, unlike existing techniques, can be used on systems with multiple measures of maximal entropy. The final project will extend recent work by the PI and Kevin McGoff on random multidimensional SFTs, in which a probabilistic framework was defined where a "typically" chosen multidimensional SFT does not exhibit the worst pathological behaviors of the class; we now plan to use this framework to prove multidimensional probabilistic versions of some classical one-dimensional results. All work will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals, conference presentations, and the author's continued collaboration with young researchers, including his two Ph.D. students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has led to significant advancement of several areas within symbolic dynamics. Symbolic dynamics studies dynamical systems given by sequences/arrays of symbols from a finite alphabet, and is important both as a tractable model for modeling other dynamical systems, and as a fundamental area in its own right. Much of the work from this project dealt with multidimensional symbolic dynamics, in which one considers not sequences, but multidimensional arrays of symbols, which can be shifted in any direction. Many questions that were easy to answer in one dimension become quite difficult, and classes of systems whose behavior was relatively simple in one dimension can exhibit strange and complex behaviors.

As described in the abstract, the progress from this grant was in four main directions.

The first direction was about the continued development of a probabilistic framework for the study of multidimensional shifts of finite type (SFTs). Previous joint work with Kevin McGoff had defined this framework, and showed that in certain senses, some strange/pathological behavior that can occur for these systems does not occur in a "typical" one. The work from this grant examined the structure of maps between SFTs in this probabilistic setting, since fundamental one-dimensional theorems such as Krieger's embedding theorem and Boyle's lower entropy factor theorem have no known two-dimensional analogues. We showed that some versions of these results hold "typically" for these systems, which is an important step towards developing a new narrative for multidimensional SFTs; instead of "results from one dimension cannot be extended to multi-dimensional versions," the truth is likely "many results from one dimension can be extended to probabilistic multi-dimensional versions." 

The second direction was about the classical specification property of Bowen. Several recent works have demonstrated that many desirable properties implied by specification in fact hold under significantly weaker versions. Several weakened specification properties exist in the literature, including the decomposition property of Climenhaga and Thompson, and non-uniform gap and non-uniform mistake specification, studied under different names by several other authors. The work in this grant made great strides in characterizing when the latter two properties imply uniqueness of the measure of maximal entropy of a subshift, finding the optimal threshold to which the properties can be weakened and still imply uniqueness. Along with Vaughn Climenhaga, we also defined a new one-sided specification property, which can be used to prove uniqueness for some new systems. These results constitute a significant advance in the burgeoning area of weakened specification properties.

The third direction was about the so-called follower/extender sets for subshifts. Extender sets are a recent object of study which generalize the better-known follower sets, and are much more suited for the study of multidimensional subshifts. In works with Nic Ormes and/or Thomas French, we proved several results developing the theory of these objects, including the development of a new conjugacy invariant, similar to the classical entropy, for subshifts, defined via extender sets. As with any new conjugacy invariant, we anticipate that this will allow for additional classification of subshifts, by adding to the relatively small set of numerical invariants allowing one to prove that a pair of subshifts is not conjugate.

The fourth and final direction was about provably polynomial-time approximation algorithms for topological pressure for new classes of multidimensional SFTs. Previously existing such algorithms relied on uniqueness of the equilibrium state/measure of maximal pressure. With Stefan Adams, Raimundo Briceno, and Brian Marcus, we were able to give the algorithms for a large class of systems without unique equilibrium state, including several well-established classical models. This represents a large advance in this area, which should lead to a greater understanding of the mechanisms behind efficient computability of pressure. 

The main outcomes of this work are eleven preprints submitted for publication during the funded period, of which four have already been published in top peer-reviewed mathematics journals. In addition, the work has been disseminated via many seminar and conference presentations, including a 1-week course at a summer school in dynamics in Seville, Spain, a 1-week mini-course at the CIRM facility in Marseille, France, and a presentation at the 2017 conference in honor of the work of Rufus Bowen at UBC in Vancouver, Canada. 

Broader Impact outcomes from this work included: organization (with Nic Ormes) of the 6th Pingree Park dynamics workshop, organization (with Nic Ormes) of a special session on zero-dimensional dynamics at a sectional meeting of the AMS, development of a mathematical exhibit for a K-7 outreach event called STEMosphere, supervision of the University of Denver Putnam exam team, and directing the University of Denver math tutoring center. In addition, the PI has stayed active in mentorship of students and young mathematicians, graduating two Ph.D. students, as well as supervising two undergraduate theses, one of which became a publication in an undergraduate mathematics journal.
